name: Analysis & Performance of Literature
subject: PERF_ST
overview:
Overview of class
	
The course studies the performance of poetry, short fiction, and non-fiction. It explores how performance helps the performer and audience to understand a text; it considers in what ways a performance can "match" a written text; and it examines the techniques of performance. Students write three critical papers and give three live, graded performances.  There are some quizzes and workshops.  The class is neither an acting class nor an English class, but it draws on practices fundamental to both. Much of class time will be devoted to performance of texts and rigorous critical discussion of the performances and the works on which they are based. Consequently, attendance is mandatory.  It examines the role of the audience in the critical reception of the text.  The course is designed for both students with little prior performance experience and those with considerable theatrical experience.

It is an excellent course for students to take who want to become excellent communicators; it hones your professional skills and gives you the poise and confidence to excel in the "real world."
attributes:
Literature & Fine Arts Distro Area

Attendance at 1st class mandatory

name: Sound and Communication Health
subject: CSD
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Students who have previously taken or are currently registered for CSD 318-0, 320-0, or 373-0 are not permitted to also register for CSD 108-0.
overview: Basic facts and principles of human communication and its disorders. Participation in or review of current research is included in this introduction to human communication science.

name: Voice for Performance
subject: THEATRE
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Theatre Majors

name: Performance Art
subject: PERF_ST
overview: This course is open to graduates and undergraduates. It focuses on the transnational histories and practices of performance art. We will investigate the poetics and embodied textures of performance art, it's pleasures and pains, recursive temporalities, and tactics of undoing and remaking space and the social. The main questions that animate the course are: What is the role of performance art in our highly mediatized culture? What kind of aesthetic and political intervention does performance art make and how has this changed historically? What forms of presence, collectivity, and memory does performance art enable as a fluid, fugitive art form with its own materiality and "staying" power? Class sessions will alternate between reading discussions, student presentations on individual artists and collectives, guest perfomers, and performance exercises. Reading materials include canonical texts as well as more recent work such as the exhibit catalogues Arte No Es Vida, Radical Presence: Black Performance in Contemporary Art and Radical Women: Latin American Art, 1960-1985. Students will develop solo and group performance pieces and will write critiques and a final paper.

name: Topics in Performance Studies
subject: PERF_ST
overview: How do sexuality, race, gender, and class shape new media? This course explores the role of intersectional identity in technological transformations in media, focusing on the transition from analog to digital. Students will read historical case studies and theoretical essays on such topics as how social media affect how queer users interact and self-identify and how race influences cable TV distribution. The course is organized into three key areas of inquiry -- culture, organization, and technology -- with the goal of understanding the complex ways they interrelate. It is rooted in black feminism and queer of color critique but introduces a range of epistemologies. It focuses on visual media - art, television, film, games, and social media.

name: Studies in Performance
subject: PERF_ST
overview: This class provides conceptual and practical tools to help students devise their performance recital. Through critical essays and performance exercises, the course engages performance as analytic, research method, and event. The course gives students the opportunity to explore elements such as text, space, objects, and storytelling from an aesthetic and critical perspective. What are the issues that are central to studies of performance when bodies are on display or when a story is communicated to an audience? In what ways does a poetic rendition of an ethnographic interview make a statement about the politics of the research process, disrupting notions of linearity and authority that characterize Western epistemology? How do narrative voice choices impact the politics of a performance? The aim of the course is to explore performance as a meaning-making practice, paying close attention to the role of embodied behavior in the production, interpretation, and dissemination of knowledge.

name: Practicum: Adaptation/Staging of Texts
subject: PERF_ST
overview:
NOTE ON ENROLLMENT.
The fall 2018 section of 424 is open to interested graduate and upper-division undergraduate
students from any program. The Practicum seminar was initially developed for first-year
students in the Theatre Department's MFA Directing Program. The section of 424 required
for 2018-19 first-year Directing MFAs will be offered, by arrangement with Jessica
Thebus and Katy Walsh, in spring 2019. If you are a first-year Directing MFA, take the
section in spring 2018, not this one.
The Practicum seminar in adaptation for first-year students in the Theatre MFA Directing Program meets once a week for three hours. The seminar addresses four topic areas.
(1) Principles of storytelling for stage adaptations of non-dramatic texts.
(2) Narrators onstage: models for the dynamic interaction of storytelling and dramatic representation.
(3) Pretext analysis: the place of appropriation, allegory, and mash-up in stage adaptation.
(4) Imagining the performance space for plays with narrators.

name: Seminar: Problems in Performance Studies
subject: PERF_ST
overview: This course examines the production and contestation of racialized meanings attached to bodies.  Focusing on performances by and about Asian Americans and African Americans, we will study how bodies are marked and redefined as "other," "oriental," "Asian," "black," "Asian American," and "African American" in relation to social violence, politics, and the law. In addition to readings in critical race theory, feminist theory, and performance theory, we will study key works in the field of theatre and performance studies that focus on the experience and performance of race.

name: Seminar: Problems in Research
subject: PERF_ST
overview: This course will introduce incoming graduate students to the field of performance studies, lay out the milestones they must meet in their graduate careers, prepare students for Master's and Dissertation research and writing, including documentation and argumentation.

name: Research Methods in Comm Studies
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Communication Studies Majors only
overview: This course provides a general overview of the important components of social science research. Through lecture, discussion, and research projects, we will cover the research process, variables and measurement, data collection and statistical analysis, hypothesis testing, experimental designs and alternative research approaches, reliability and validity, ethical principles in conducting research, and writing research reports using APA style. These concepts will be examined through reviews of: survey research, evaluation research, qualitative studies, and content analysis. Much of the course will rely on evaluation and analysis of published scientific articles focusing on the specific research methods used in order to fully understand the research process.
attributes:
Attendance at 1st class mandatory

Undergraduate Students Only

name: Theories of Persuasion
subject: COMM_ST
overview: This course provides a general introduction to the social-scientific study of persuasive communication. The course focuses on alternative theoretical accounts of the processes underlying persuasion and on research findings concerning the effects of various factors on persuasive effectiveness.

name: Principles of Rhetorical Criticism
subject: COMM_ST
overview: Introduction to techniques of rhetorical analysis for use in describing, evaluating, and participating in discussions of public issues. Historical and contemporary examples of public discourse illuminate how symbolic action affects decision making and power relations in public life.

name: Communication and Culture
subject: COMM_ST
overview: This course examines how communication and culture are mutually constitutive. We explore theoretical foundations of cultural studies and case studies that illustrate the complexities of representing culture.

name: Philosophy of Language & Communication
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Juniors & Seniors
overview: In this course, students implement tools of philosophical analysis to interrogate basic, taken-for-granted premises about human language and communication. We explore ethical questions posed by animal communication, new modes of communication, and cultural norms. Students will learn how to identify and systematically dissect these unacknowledged precepts and beliefs, with the ultimate goal of reconstituting them into your own well-reasoned, personally satisfying philosophy of communication.

name: Team Leadership and Decision Making
subject: COMM_ST
overview: The past two decades have witnessed a fundamental transformation in the nature of work. Trends towards empowerment, digitization, and globalization have resulted in organizations that routinely structure work around teams. Teams connect diverse, distributed individuals, empowering them to work collaboratively. Those working in, leading, and studying teams have repeatedly observed that teams can accomplish more than the sum or member capabilities (i.e., synergy), but often accomplish less than would the same individuals working alone (i.e., process loss). This course will explore the forces that affect behavior in teams, and the factors that lead to team success. The course will explore the specific challenges associated with leading teams, some of which include: building and designing teams, managing information sharing within and across teams, structuring effective group decision processes, igniting creative thinking, enabling complex problem solving, managing team diversity and conflict, and managing teams of teams. This is an introductory course, with no prerequisites. We will use a variety of readings, activities, and class activities to build team leadership skills. Because of the experiential nature of the course, attendance at all class meetings is required.

name: Theories of Organizational Communication
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Juniors & Seniors
overview: This is a survey of theory and research focused on communication in the workplace.

name: Theories of Mediated Communication
subject: COMM_ST
overview: The aim of this course is to help you understand the roles and activities of mass media in U. S. society. By the end of the semester you will have a much better sense than you now do of the forces that guide the books we read, movies we enjoy, television shows we watch and even the toys we buy. You will also be able to understand theories, industry jargon and knowledgably discuss industry trends from a wide spectrum of media industries. The course will be comprised of two (1 hour, 20 minute) lectures a week, readings from the required textbook, 1 paper, and 2 exams, with the second exam taking place during the final class.
attributes:
Attendance at 1st class mandatory

Undergraduate Students Only

name: Persuasive Images: Rhetoric of Popular Culture
subject: COMM_ST
overview: The course analyzes persuasion in the business of popular culture. The student is introduced to strategies and tactics that influence audiences in a fragmented and competitive marketplace through public communications, advertising, and marketing. The subject material includes film, television, celebrity, music, the Internet, social media, shopping centers and supermarkets, car lots, sports, fashion, and other everyday media and entertainment communication experiences.

name: Media & Publics Across Cultures
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors from every undergraduate school only. First year students need permission to enroll into the course.
overview: This course examines what it means to study "culture" in a world in which people, ideas, and capital move more easily than ever across national borders. Drawing on resources from cultural studies, ethnography, and literature studies, students will explore "international" and "transnational" approaches to understanding media and culture.

name: Rhetorical History of the United States III
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors from every undergraduate school only. First year students need permission to enroll into the course.
overview: In this course, students explore US history from WWI to the 1960s through an examination of interesting and influential rhetorical acts. The course will address relevant examples of oratory, visual rhetoric, and other acts of persuasion by major political actors. It will also address less traditional modes of popular and countercultural persuasion.

name: Community Integration of Labeled People
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors from every undergraduate school only. First year students need permission to enroll into the course.
overview: We investigate the theories and practices of integrating people with physical and mental differences into everyday society. People with these differences and their supporters regularly help teach the class.

name: Interpersonal Conflict
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Communication Studies Juniors and Seniors.
overview: This course is focused on processes observed in interpersonal disputes. Causes of conflict and methods of resolution will be discussed. Sources of information will include research and theory drawn from communication, social psychology, sociology, and organizational behavior. The course will include general models of conflict as well as material related to disagreements in specific contexts such as friendship, dating, and marriage. The primary method of teaching will be lecture and students are encouraged to ask questions and offer examples

name: Family Communication
subject: COMM_ST
overview: This course address family relationships and there communication processes, or how members interact, create, and maintain families across the years. Topics include: intimacy and conflict patterns, developmental stages, developmental and unpredictable stressors.

name: Bargaining and Negotiation
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Communication Studies Juniors and Seniors.
overview: 363 focuses upon a variety of theories and research projects that explain and predict behavior within negotiation contexts. These theories will be drawn from a variety of disciplines including organizational behavior, industrial relations, political science, social psychology, and communication. Obviously, much of the class material will be drawn from social scientific theory and research. We will also focus on negotiation within a variety of contexts including collective bargaining, family interactions, sales, and international diplomacy. The primary method of teaching will be lecture and students are encouraged to ask questions and offer examples.

name: Ethnographies of Culture
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors from every undergraduate school only. First year students need permission to enroll into the course.

name: Cultural Analytics
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors from every undergraduate school only. First year students need permission to enroll into the course.
overview: Big Data is currency to those initiated in the nuts and bolts of data science. Building on simple real-world examples and exercises that build data literacy, this course introduces key concepts and methods selected from recent interdisciplinary research on networks, social media, machine learning, the wisdom of crowds, and prediction markets. Cultural Analytics provides you with tools to apply this research to make predictions about the market for cultural goods like music, film, books, and computer games. It explores factors that make prediction hard (e.g., social influence, ICTs, and the new digital economy) and gives you alternatives using the potential of Big Data. Specifically, you will learn how to plot and interpret graphs to measure performance in cultural markets; use Internet search data and Twitter conversations to forecast trends; build, visualize, and explore networks; train machine learning algorithms for prediction; and harness the wisdom of crowds. Additionally, some practical components of the course will teach you how to work with IBM's Watson Analytics, an easy-to-use yet powerful and comprehensive data analysis tool. The course provides core data science and modeling skills as well as "soft skills" like problem-solving, communication, and project management. Its main goals are to help you recognize the potential of Big Data-driven approaches and equip you with the knowledge to critically assess the quality of your findings. Except an open mind, there are no prerequisites for the class. While formal thinking is encouraged, the course focuses on providing conceptual foundations and hands-on tools that apply across a variety of creative sectors.
attributes:
Attendance at 1st class mandatory

Undergraduate Students Only

name: The Sociology of Online News
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors from every undergraduate school only. First year students need permission to enroll into the course.
overview: The goal of this upper-level undergraduate seminar is to survey sociological research on online news. This is an area of inquiry that examines the interpersonal, organizational, institutional, technological, political and cultural factors that shape the production and consumption of news online. This is a new and emerging area that draws from sociological studies of traditional (print and broadcast) media to understand the construction and use of online news. However, in comparison to the slow-moving sociology of news in traditional media, with its relatively established theories and objects of inquiry, scholarship about online news is a fast-moving area because both the phenomena under consideration and the ways of making sense of them have been in ongoing transformation since its inception. The content and organization of this seminar reflect the fast-moving character of the sociology of online news, emphasizing relatively recent texts but grounding their interpretation in longstanding debates in the sociology of traditional media.

name: Topics in Communication Studies
subject: COMM_ST
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors from every undergraduate school only. First year students need permission to enroll into the course.
overview: This course explores health communication from a design perspective. In this course students will explore factors that make conversations in health "difficult," and the possible strategies to overcome such difficulties. By the end of this course students should be able to critically examine difficult conversations in health and have the skills to propose interventions to overcome them.

name: Seminar-Problems in Comm Studies
subject: COMM_ST
overview: The seminar discusses selected topics and texts from twentieth and twenty-first century rhetorical theory.

name: Perspectives on Human Communication
subject: MSC
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Only students in the MSC Custom Leadership Program may enroll in this class.
overview: This introductory course surveys interpersonal, small-group and organizational communication theories, bringing students up-to-date on recent theories that will be useful in subsequent courses as well as in professional situations. Students develop the ability to read and analyze communication research and to apply it to their own organization situations.

name: Strategy in the Global Economy
subject: MSC
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Only students in the MSC Custom Leadership Program may enroll in this class.

name: Understanding & Leveraging Networks
subject: MSC
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Only students in the MSC Custom Leadership Program may enroll in this class.

name: Leadership & Decision Making
subject: MSC
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Only students in the MSC Custom Leadership Program may enroll in this class.
overview: This course investigates how individuals influence group decisions. Students are video-taped in decision-making interactions in order to assess and improve their leadership and analytical thinking skills in groups.

name: Methods of Research on Organizational Decision Making
subject: MSC
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Only students in the MSC Custom Leadership Program may enroll in this class.

name: Change Management
subject: MSC
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Only students in the MSC Custom Leadership Program may enroll in this class.

name: Current Issues in Law, Technology and Strategy
subject: MSC
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Only students in the MSC Custom Leadership Program may enroll in this class.

name: Seminar-Problems in Comm Studies
subject: COMM_ST
requirements:
Enrollment Requirements: REASON: Pre-registration is not allowed for this class. Please try again during regular registration.

Reserved for Graduate Students.

name: First-Year Topics Seminar
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for School of Communication students.
overview: In this course we will view, discuss, and write about films that take a look at other media - at "Stop the presses!" newspaper reporting, authoritative industry magazines, and investigative journalism; at radio news broadcasts, call-in talk shows, and music programs as reflection of an era; at television as a source/maker of news, as an agent of political/social change, and as entertainment; and at dissemination of information via the internet.  We will consider the tension revealed in films which present varying perspectives on print, broadcast, and internet media operations.  Are the media operating for the common good or ill, to reveal or to hide corruption in business and government, and/or to raise the level of public discourse or pander to the uninformed masses?  Especially in this election year, what sources of news do you trust to give you accurate information, and which are manipulating facts to further an agenda or merely to entertain? We will use these films to generate lively class discussions and rich paper topics.

name: Analyzing Media Texts
subject: RTVF
overview: This course is an introduction to the study and structure of film and other audiovisual media. We will define and examine the expressive and aesthetic power of the basic elements of the moving image. Specifically, the course will investigate, across a variety of different media, modes, and historical periods, the fundamentals of cinematography, especially the shot and its composition; editing; set design, costume, and acting styles; and sound. We will also discuss narrative, genre, documentary, animation, and experimental film. The goal of the course is to acquaint students with a vocabulary specific to film and other audiovisual media, and to provide students with the critical tools required for the accurate description and analysis of the moving image.

name: Studies in Media Topics
subject: RTVF
overview: This course examines how power is created, sustained and challenged in entertainment media. Students will learn how and why individuals, groups and corporations achieve and maintain dominance in art, film, television, gaming and digital and social media. Particular attention will be paid to how industries have survived the digital transition. Readings will explore contemporary case studies and debates. Lectures will give theoretical and historical context. This course is intended as an introduction to creative industries and first in a sequence before "Contemporary Television."

name: History of Film I
subject: RTVF
overview:
This course surveys the history of international cinema from its emergence through the 1930s.  We will explore the diverse forms cinema took and functions it performed during this period by looking closely at a range of films and writings about them. We will examine the industrial, social, and historical contexts within which these films were produced and experienced as well as theorizations of cinema that emerged concurrently with them. The course thus introduces students to the study of film history as well as to key national and international trends in making and thinking about cinema as it rose to prominence as a vital component of the art and culture of the twentieth century.

Topics covered include the cinema of attractions; the development of narrative filmmaking in the United States and Europe; the studio systems of Hollywood and Japan; exhibition practices; the concept of national cinemas as exemplified by the cinemas of France, Germany, and the Soviet Union; the avant-garde and cinema's relation to art movements; the coming of synchronized sound; documentary cinema; and diverse conceptualizations of cinema's political possibilities and dangers.

name: History of Film II
subject: RTVF
overview: This course will attempt to account for major theoretical, industrial, aesthetic, and political developments in international postwar cinema. Contemporary and historical texts will be presented and discussed in class sessions to inform an understanding of critical issues in the evolution of narrative cinema from 1948-2000. Films from Alfred Hitchcock, Jean-Luc Godard, Agnes Varda, and Barbara Kopple, among others, will be screened. Readings include essays from Andre Bazin, Linda Williams, bell hooks, and Peter Wollen.

name: Doc Film History & Criticism
subject: RTVF
overview: This course provides a survey of the history, politics, aesthetics, and ethical questions central to documentary cinema. We will view significant films in the history of documentary from the silent era to the digital age. Course readings and screenings will prompt students to discuss various frameworks used to define "documentary,' analyze a range of approaches to nonfiction film form, and examine the shifting social, cultural, political concerns raised by documentary filmmakers. In doing so, we will also explore technological constrains and advancements related to the field of documentary, as well as the social-cultural meanings or possibilities produced through documentary practice. Students will  be asked to post short discussion responses to Canvas about weekly screenings and readings, write a midterm analysis paper that will be developed into a larger final research project, and take a final exam to synthesize core concepts from the course.
attributes:
Literature & Fine Arts Distro Area

Attendance at 1st class mandatory
topic: Art of the Real: A History of Documentary

name: Radio/Television/Film Genre
subject: RTVF
overview: This course will introduce students to masterpieces of an art form that's long been forgotten, but is in the midst of rebirth: radio drama. In the middle decades of the 20th century, radio plays were among the most popular forms of fiction in many parts of the world. Legends have come down about thrillers of the 1930s, but these remain poorly understood, and are not representative of the broad work of experimental writers in the medium. In this class you will learn how radio dramas were made in three historical periods: classic American (1937-54); mid-century British (1954-1974) and contemporary global traditions. We will explore the cultural and political background of each of these contexts, practice how to "read" a radio play, and even do some dramatic radio writing.  Some radio dramatists we will consider include: Samuel Beckett, Neil Gaiman, Dylan Thomas, Langston Hughes, Orson Welles, Lucille Fletcher, Tom Stoppard, Gregory Whitehead, Ray Bradbury, Eli Horowitz and Harold Pinter. Students with a background or interest in media history, podcasts, creative writing, theatre history, performance, voice studies or literature are especially welcome.

name: Film, Media & Gender
subject: RTVF
overview: This course explores the ways gender, as well as other intersectional axes of difference including sexuality and race, factors into media production, representation, and audience activity. In particular, we'll focus on gender across two predominant media platforms: film and television. We'll also consider gender within both mainstream and independent media production and explore how gender is used to study, construct, and address media audiences. Overall, this course will address how difference becomes a tool of social, cultural, economic, and political power, and how its use both empowers and disempowers various cultural groups.

name: Film & TV Criticism
subject: RTVF
overview: This seminar focuses on formulaic television, from classic episodic programs (e.g. Perry Mason or The Beverly Hillbillies) to contemporary lifestyle TV (e.g. Cupcake Wars or Say Yes to the Dress).  Because of their rote predictability, these programs are commonly written off as blandly reassuring (e.g. House Hunters), as guilty pleasures (Hallmark Christmas movies), or as just plain boring.  At the same time, the meanings of formulaic TV shows are considered quite obvious, based on the simple, repetitive formula.  This class challenges the adequacy of these approaches.  We look closely and carefully at formulaic television, challenging received assumptions about quality, complexity, and value that dominate current cultural discourses about television.  We wonder about the relationship (or difference) between reassuring predictability and boredom; we ask how a TV show that bores some people captivates others, who may in turn watch an equally formulaic program instead; we downplay the importance of the formula as the sole generator of meaning and feeling.

name: National Cinema
subject: RTVF
overview: The goal of this course is to provide students with a firm understanding of the major contributions of Russian film art to world cinema, especially what is often termed Russian, or dialectical, montage, introduced in the early 20th century by Lev Kuleshov and developed by Sergei Eisenstein. Students are expected to gain knowledge in classic Russian cinematography, as well as in the theatrical "method" of Stanislavsky and "biomechanics" of Meyerhold that were influential in shaping Russian film theory and history. In class, students will watch the major films by Protazanov, Eisenstein, Pudovkin, and Vertov and discuss them with the Professor. The primary texts for the course will be the films themselves, but the most important theoretical essays by Kuleshov, Eisenstein, Pudovkin, and Vertov will be provided during the course and discussed in class.

name: Topics in Media Writing
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Students must have taken RTVF 260-0 in order to register for this course.
overview: From the surprise ending, to the unexpected second act twist, to the slow-dawning realization, narratives from Oedipus to The Sixth Sense are so often structured around the Big Reveal. "SPOILER ALERT: Writing the Dramatic Surprise" is a course in the mechanics of how the best of those reveals are crafted.
topic: Spoiler Alert: Writing the Dramatic Surprise

name: Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisite: Students must have taken and passed RTVF 190-0.
overview: This course is an introduction to a range of Experimental Animation Techniques, including direct on film, cut-outs, clay, object, sand, paint on glass, and pixellation.  Students will view canonical films that use these techniques, and complete weekly exercises that allow an introduction to a range of graphic styles.

name: Lighting and Cinematography
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisite: Students must have taken and passed RTVF 190-0.
overview:
This is one of the cornerstone classes of your production experience in the film department at NU. You'll be introduced to Super 16mm film via the Arri SRII. You'll master the bulk of the lightin and grip equipment in the cage. You'll learn about light, color, lenses, emulsion, and film stocks. As well, you'll review the Panasonic HPX.
In addition to the technical side of cinematography, you will begin to explore the artistic side of this art. You will expand on your work in 190 by examining framing and composition, light and shadow, and color as they apply to the moving image. You will work rigorously on your ability to translate meaning, story, and idea into image. As well, you will gain more experience in the collaborative process which is critical in the filmmaking arts.
attributes:
Attendance at 1st class mandatory

Prerequisites apply, see description

name: Introduction to Sound Postproduction
subject: RTVF
overview: This course is an introduction to the theories and principles of basic sound production. Through demos, lectures, readings, screenings and exercises, students will be exposed to all of the basics of sound recording technology: the physical properties of sound, microphone design and technique, recording technology, basic mixing and effects, playback and output, and relevant techniques for working in diverse environments for various types of sound recording. Students will practice various kinds of active listening, both to develop troubleshooting techniques and a more sophisticated approach to sound design.
attributes:
Prerequisites apply, see description

No Freshmen

name: Documentary Production
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisite: Students must have taken and passed RTVF 190-0.
overview: In this course, students will examine documentary practices and produce their own shorts. Students will be guided through all the necessary pre-production, production and post-production steps and will create a finished short documentary ready to submit to film festivals, online outlets, or other exhibition venues by the end of the quarter. Students may choose to co-direct with another classmate or work solo. A working knowledge of basic production equipment and editing software is expected, but refresher workshops will be offered as needed. Watching, discussing, and providing feedback for students' work will be a major component of this class. We will also look at a range of documentaries in class to analyze different styles and strategies.

name: Symposium: Issues in RTVF
subject: RTVF
overview: This course traces representations of Chicago in narrative film from the silent era to the present day. We will watch both mainstream and independently produced films shot on-location in the city, placing them into social-historical contexts related to Chicago's built environment, local culture, and political history. A particular emphasis will be placed on the ways local minorities have been portrayed on screen in relation to the urban spaces they inhabit. This course will encourage students to think critically about the way cultural understandings of race, gender, class, and politics have been produced, sustained, or challenged through cinematic visions of the city. Local film will likewise serve as a lens to examine broader concerns in Film Studies, including authorship, genre, and aesthetics. At the end of the quarter, students will not only have a deeper understanding of local history, but also new perspectives on the complex relationship between filmmaking, citizenship, and urban life in the 20th and 21st Centuries.
topic: Visions of the City: Chicago in Film HIstory and C

name: Media Historiography
subject: RTVF
overview: This course explores the cultural and social history of film, television, and digital media. We will look at scholarship in cultural history, archive theory, media archology, and literary inspired histories of texts and readers, and we evaluate their usefulness for media studies.  The course will introduce historical models through which to understand how audiences have gathered as publics for media, and we will explore how media audiences  have  been mobilized as political communities. We will also examine the contemporary media's role in constructing historical consciousness for audiences. We'll consider how memory serves as a source of alternative historical knowledge that challenges official histories, and we will explore, for example, how people use share sites (like YouTube) to curate and share alternative archives.

name: Global Media
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Screen Cultures PhD students or by permission of instructor.
overview: Cinema has been global from the start and throughout its history displaced artists have made films that enriched the cinemas of both their homeland and adopted lands. The films made by refugee, expatriate, exile, migr, postcolonial, and transnational subjects are usually discussed under the rubrics of national cinemas, auteurism, genre cinema, or diaspora cinema. The purpose of this course, however, is to problematize these concepts, particularly in the light of the current forms of displacement and globalization. It examines the extent to which such films constitute a new mode of production and a new accented or transnational style?a style that signifies and signifies upon displacement and globalization.

name: Advanced Seminar in Film & Video
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Screen Cultures PhD students or by permission of instructor.
overview: This course will take a cultural and historical approach to auditory experience, and so serve as an introduction to the field of Sound Studies: the analysis of sonic practices and the discourses and institutions that shape and describe them. Sound Studies is defined by its interdisciplinary nature, and over the course of the quarter we will encounter work on popular music, the cinematic soundtrack, the history of sound technologies, the experience of listening, the social politics of the voice, and the sonic dimension of the lived environment. Though much of our emphasis will be on intersections of sound and popular forms of media, we will also have occasion to consider various forms of sound technology, sound art, and sound performance. The turn towards sound in humanities research has the potential to decenter dominant modes of thinking as well as to recover aspects of history and experience now forgotten or obscured. Inspired by that potential, we will consider questions such as: What methodologies best enable the study of sound? How can we write a history of auditory experience? How has listening changed in the era of modern media? How can we understand the ethical dimensions of listening? How are sounds combined with mediated images and associated with particular bodies? What is the relationship between the voice and identity? How might a focus on sound facilitate new encounters with the environment and its human and nonhuman inhabitants?

name: Advanced Media Writing
subject: RTVF
overview:
To provide students with the tools necessary to pitch, develop, and write a pilot episode of an original half- hour single camera comedy.  Current television pilots and series will be analyzed. 
 
The class will replicate as much as possible the atmosphere of the "writers' room" on a sitcom during production. As with a real sitcom staff, the class will offer constructive criticism of each other's work. The various roles in the writer's room will also be explored. Students will pitch an idea for a half hour single camera show and work with other writers on developing a script. 
**syllabus subject to change as needed.

name: Advanced Editing
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Registration is reserved for Documentary Media MFA Students.

name: Grad Prod Wkshop
subject: RTVF
overview: Students will be introduced to the technical and theoretical components necessary for media construction: narrative, sound, image, and editing. Projects will include audio and video exercises and will culminate in the production of group short films.

name: Advanced Cinematography
subject: RTVF
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Registration is restricted to RTVF Majors who have taken RTVF 380-0.
overview: This class will continue in your development as a visual artist in moving images by focusing on advanced ideas of coverage, craft, and lighting. You will focus your personal style and develop it, as well as increase your body of knowledge and skill set in cinematography: lighting, lenses, cameras, and techniques. This class will continue work in Super 16mm cinematography begun in RTVF 380, and will also incorporate DSLR cinematography with the Canon 5D Mark III, as well as the potential for other cameras. We will work with advanced lighting techniques and equipment, coverage concepts, and problem solving.

name: Seminar: Studies in Film and Video Prod
subject: RTVF
overview: This course is focused on expanding students' foundational knowledge of cinematography, sound recording, lighting, and editing specifically for documentary projects. Initially using the Canon C100 camera, students will learn to master the technical and aesthetic challenges and opportunities of shooting non-fiction. Using Adobe Premiere Pro CC software, the editing portion of the course will cover theoretical, organizational, and practical aspects of documentary post-production. The exercises and assignments in this course will build practical skills, while also allowing for aesthetic exploration. Class time will be devoted to the introduction of concepts and various technologies, in-class exercises, viewing relevant documentaries, discussion of techniques, and providing feedback for students' work.

name: Research Seminar
subject: RTVF
overview: What is a woman's genre?  Why and how are certain modes and genres of media culture seen as belonging to women?  And how have those forms been valued (and/or devalued) in the larger culture?  The class considers these issues, and the different ways in which they have been understood.   We also look at some of the different, even contradictory ways in which women's popular media culture has been theorized and interpreted.  We consider print, film, television, and digital/social media in these terms and engage with scholars from across the past 40-plus years.

name: Seminar in Communication Sciences & Disorders
subject: CSD
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Freshmen
overview:
Course Description:    Freshman Seminar
Major topics of research interest in communicative disorders. Principles of research in communicative disorders.

The majority of the world population is bilingual or multilingual. Experiencing the world through more than one language impacts not only communication with others, but also how one perceives and processes the surrounding environment. Converging evidence from the growing field of bilingual research reveals that learning, using, and managing two languages has profound consequences for linguistic, cognitive and neural function. Throughout this course, students will consider what it means to be "bilingual", and explore how bilingualism shapes human communication, including language development and learning, the production and perception of speech, cognitive function, and neural activity, as well as the perceived benefits and pitfalls of bilingualism from a cognitive and educational perspective.

name: Neurobiology of Communication
subject: CSD
overview: Human anatomy, physiology, and neurology in relation to communicative behavior. Sensory, perceptual, cognitive, and motor processes. This course is intended to introduce students to basic neurophysiological principles related to human communication.  Basic mechanisms underlying the function of the nervous system beginning with single cells and progressing up through simple reflexes to more complex functions related to speech-language-hearing will be addressed.  Sensory systems including the auditory, visual and somatosensory systems will be discussed in context to their relevance to communication and communication disorders.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of the Vocal Mechanism
subject: CSD
overview: This course provides basic information on the anatomy and physiology of structures important for speech production. The course begins with a description of basic properties of cells, tissues and systems common to all parts of the body. The course then proceeds through each of three systems important for speech production: the respiratory, laryngeal and articulatory systems. In each system, anatomy of the structural components are first presented, i.e., bones, soft tissues and muscles, followed by presentations of the physiological interactions of the structural features. Within each system, various disease and pathological conditions that relate to speech production are also presented. The lectures are augmented by a weekly lab session in which students are exposed to dissections of cadaveric material as well as anatomical models.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of the Peripheral Hearing Mechanism
subject: CSD

name: Statistics in Communication Sciences and Disorders
subject: CSD

name: Psychoacoustics
subject: CSD
overview: Psychoacoustics is the study of the relationship between the physical characteristics of acoustic stimuli and the hearing sensations that those stimuli elicit. Thus, this course is about the perception of sound.  Topics covered include sound, the auditory system, psychophysical methods, frequency selectivity, timing, sound-source localization, intensity and loudness, frequency and pitch, and perceptual learning. Examples are drawn from both normal and impaired hearing.  Grading is based on a set of assignments and two exams.

name: Experimental Design and Statistics in Communication Sciences and Disorders
subject: CSD

name: Experimental Design and Statistics in Communication Sciences and Disorders
subject: CSD
overview: Course Description:   Second Quarter: Covariance, factor, and nonparametric analysis. Multivariate procedures and test statistics; research applications.

name: Scientific Writing
subject: CSD
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for CSD PhD Students Only.
overview: The purpose of this course is to help students master the fundamentals of written scientific argumentation for grants and journal articles, improve the organization and clarity of their writing, identify strategies for revision, and appreciate the importance of writing in their scientific careers.  Emphasis is placed on the distinction between hypotheses and predictions.

name: Introduction to Audiology
subject: CSD
overview: Course Description:    Introduction to the measurement of hearing in humans. Basic anatomy of the ear, measurement of hearing, potential disorders of hearing.  This course is an introduction to audiology, which is a branch of science that studies hearing, balance and their related disorders. Its specialists, known as audiologist, are trained health-care professionals that specialize in identifying, diagnosing, treating and monitoring hearing and balance disorders. Audiologists use various testing strategies to determine whether an individual can hear within normal limits or if a balance problem exists. If a hearing loss or balance problem is identified, audiologists determine the region(s) of the system that are affected and the extent of the disorder

name: Pathologies of the Auditory System
subject: CSD
requirements:
Enrollment Requirements: REASON: Pre-registration is not allowed for this class. Please try again during regular registration.

Reserved for Doctor of Audiology students only.

name: Evaluation and Use of Amplification Systems
subject: CSD
overview: Course Description:     Electroacoustic characteristics of hearing aids, selection of individual and group amplification systems, and client management.  This course covers the knowledge and skills required to select, fit, adjust, and validate hearing aids.  In the first half of the class, we review hearing aid technology and the decisions based on that technology.  In the second half of the class, we consider fitting and adjustment of the hearing aid.

name: Evaluation of the Peripheral Hearing Mechanism
subject: CSD

name: Evaluation and Treatment of Central Auditory Processing Disorders
subject: CSD

name: Electrophysiology of the Human Auditory System
subject: CSD
overview: Neuroanatomical and neurophysiological bases of human auditory evoked responses; administration and interpretation of the procedures used in evoked response testing; and relationship between pathophysiology and evoked response results. Hands-on laboratory experience.

name: Amplification Systems II
subject: CSD
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Doctor of Audiology students only.
overview: Advanced amplification, including alternatives to traditional hearing aids such as over-the-counter (OTC) amplification and personal sound amplification processors (PSAPs).  Hearing assistive technology, and personal and group amplification options. Focus on adult device use.

name: Seminar: Experimental and Theoretical Aspects of Audiology
subject: CSD

name: Early Communication Intervention With Infants and Toddlers
subject: CSD
overview:
Course Description:    
   Provides information on issues and practices related to early intervention and working with families who have children with special needs. Provides strategies for: (a) assessing communication in natural environments, (b) supporting language during routines, (c) communicating and collaborating effectively with parents. Topics include family and professional relationships, models of working with families, service coordination, family assessment and the Individual Family Service Plans, promoting family participation, coaching, media and technology and cultural considerations.

name: Diagnostic & Remedial Approaches for Children With Learning Problems
subject: CSD

name: Attention Deficit Disorder and Related Disorders
subject: CSD
overview: Identification and treatment of attention deficit disorders and related childhood behavior disorders. Emphasis on objective and subjective assessment, life-span issues, and medical and psychological interventions.

name: Delivery Systems in Speech & Language Pathology
subject: CSD
overview: Focus on the professional issues that are critical to function as a well-prepared speech-language pathologist in school, health care, and private practice settings. Areas of emphasis include but are not limited to: ethics, scope of practice, service delivery, support personnel, relevant legislation, policies and guidelines, Common Core State Standards, managed care, professional association governance, certification and licensure, collaboration, private and government health insurance, reimbursement, and advocacy.

name: Special Topics in Communication Sciences and Disorders
subject: CSD
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Only CSD Graduate Students may register for this class

name: Language Development and Usage
subject: CSD
overview:
Course Description:     Development of language at all levels (phonological, morphological, syntactic, semantic, and pragmatic), both typical and atypical. Influences of culture, individual differences, biology, and family environment. Focus on research and implications for clinical practice. 

Description, Key Questions Addressed, and Objectives: 
 	Language is a complex skill unique to human beings. How does this remarkable skill develop? What are the environmental and biological factors necessary for successful language development, and what can we learn about this process through the study of atypical language development? How can this knowledge guide clinical practice?
 	This class will explore the course of language development across key domains of language - phonology, morphology, semantics, syntax, pragmatics - and consider the major theories of language development and its biological basis. We will also cover methods for studying language over the lifespan, and study patterns of language development in particular language-impaired populations both as a guide for understanding the nature and course of language growth in developmental disabilities of language and communication, as well as how such developmental patterns may inform understanding of the biological and experiential influences on language development and use in typical development.

name: Adult Neuromotor Speech Disorders
subject: CSD
overview: Course Description:    Examination of the potential etiologies and characteristics of motor speech disorders in adults, including acoustic, perceptual, physiologic, and neurologic correlates. Focus on assessment, diagnosis, and effective treatment. Emphasis on the integration of normative data, scientific knowledge, and clinical practice.

name: Swallow Physiology and Pathology
subject: CSD
overview: Exploration of the anatomy and physiology of normal swallowing and the anatomic and physiologic disturbances affecting deglutition. Focus on recognizing clinical and radiographic signs and symptoms of dysphagia and selection and implementation of treatment and management. Discussion of ethical considerations. Emphasis on the integration of normative data, scientific knowledge, and clinical practice.

name: Pediatric Language Disorders
subject: CSD
overview:
Overview of class  
 
This course provides an overview of potential etiologies and characteristics of language disorders in children from infancy through adolescence. There is a focus on assessment, diagnosis, and effective treatment of children with specific language impairments, autism spectrum disorders, and cognitively based language impairments as well as the interplay between language, learning, and literacy. Emphasis on the integration of normative data, scientific knowledge, and clinical practice.

name: Fluency and Fluency Disorders
subject: CSD

name: Acquired Neurolinguistic and Neurocognitive Disorders
subject: CSD
overview: There are a number of assessment measures and treatment approaches that have been published in the area of acquired neurocognitive and neurolinguistic disorders. This is an evolving area of clinical practice in which new evidence is constantly emerging. The purpose of the course is NOT to teach the mechanics/procedures for performing these assessments or conducting these interventions. You will acquire the more procedural aspects of this area of practice in your simulation labs and clinical placements (and throughout your clinical career). The overarching purpose of the course IS to provide you with psycholinguistic and person-centered frameworks and theories/principles for assessment and intervention across a number of neurocognitive and neurolinguistic disorders to facilitate critical thinking and a systematic approach to clinical problem solving in these populations.

name: Advanced Treatment: Clinical Procedures in Speech and Language Pathology
subject: CSD

name: Directed Teaching in Communication Sciences and Disorders
subject: CSD
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for CSD PhD Students Only.

name: Theatre in Context: Introduction
subject: THEATRE
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Theatre Majors
attributes:
Attendance at 1st class mandatory

Department Majors Only

name: Theatre in Context: Analysis & Research
subject: THEATRE
overview: It is widely understood that we currently live in a "global" age, in which ideas, people, and commodities circulate and are connected with one another in a networked world. But what are the recent histories of this particular configuration of economic, political, and cultural affairs? And how does theatre speak to conditions of life in such a globalized world? This course will introduce students to ways of seeing the histories and present potential of theatre and performance in the time of globalization. We will discuss the histories of familiar "global" texts, analyze moments of encounter between actors and ideas in circulation, and consider the role of transnational activist performance in our present moment. Along the way, we will reflect upon our own social roles as spectators of such performances, and the critical task of translating our experiences of viewing/reading into writing.
topic: Theatre in the Time of Globalization

name: Acting I
subject: THEATRE
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Registration is reserved for sophomore, junior, and seniors in the Acting track.
overview: The acting course at NU is a developmental course of three years that teaches the study of theatre, and particularly dramatic literature, from the actor's point of view. Much of what we do seeks to establish strong group dynamics so the acting cohort and teacher stay together for the three years. The first year's study concentrates on the actor's creative capacities, and the communicating instrument is the self. The primary creative responsibility of the actor is to generate human character within the given circumstances of a play. While each teacher organizes the work individually, all agree on fundamentals, which include: Sensory Perception and Response, Observation, Imagination, Dramatic Character Creation, and Text Analysis.Get permission number, have fulfilled freshman prereq., be a theater major

name: Modern & Contemp Theatre: Modern
subject: THEATRE
overview: This course charts the paradox of the avant-garde as a Western performance tradition in the long twentieth century. How does the "avant-garde"--as a concept, ideology, praxis, and tradition--index an intellectual impulse that persists in the transition from modernity to a post-modern theatre? Beginning with some very early theoretical treatises, including Marx's The Communist Manifesto (1848), Gautier's The Canons of Bohemia (1836), and continuing all the way through to Reza Abdoh's late-twentieth century articulation of the death of the avant-garde, the course tracks the intimate, fraught, noncontiguous relationship  between the intellectual impulses of the Left with avant-garde theatrical practices.

name: Modern & Contemp Theatre: Contemporary
subject: THEATRE
overview: Neoliberalism is the belief that unregulated markets and private enterprise will eventually lead to prosperity for all. Since the 1980s, neoliberalism has been the dominant strain in Anglo-American economic and political thought.  When the Cold War ended in the mid-1990s, neoliberalism spread around the globe. Socialism had been discredited. Capitalism had been vindicated.  The main result, however, was not the universal prosperity that neoliberals promised.  Instead, the rich became much richer, while almost everyone else either became poorer, or improved their lives only marginally.  In this class, we will read a selection of successful, challenging plays that have been produced during this time.  Among the writers we will study will be Caryl Churchill, John Guare, David Henry Hwang, and August Wilson.  As we read these plays, we will also read other textsjournalism, economic history, and social theorythat will help us flesh out the complex and pressure-laden cultural contexts in which these plays exist. As we compare and contrast dramatic texts to texts from other genres, we will try to come to a realistic view of the constraints and the possibilities that characterize contemporary theatre practices during this time of ever-widening economic, cultural, and symbolic inequity.

name: Advanced Stage Management
subject: THEATRE
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Theatre Majors

name: Gender & Performance
subject: THEATRE
overview: American actresses, playwrights, dancers and choreographers did not always participate in the organized feminist movements of the 20th century. Yet their representations of gender and sexuality challenged preexisting images of women onstage and offstage. This course follows changing representations of women in theatrical performance from the late 19th century through the early 21st century. Of particular interest are domesticity as setting and problematic, solo performance, all-female ensembles, dream ballets and anti-realist breaks in the action, and works that fuse dance, music, and theatre. Readings, lectures, discussions, and video viewings are supplemented by attendance at live theatre. This course fulfills the Dance Studies requirement for Dance majors and minors, the History/Literature/Criticism requirement for Theatre majors, and the Identities Communities and Social Practices (ICSP) requirement for English majors. Open registration through English and Gender and Sexuality Studies; no permission number required.

name: Acting II: Analysis and Performance
subject: THEATRE
overview: In the second year we study the traditional canon of Western Drama to discover what each contributes to the theory, principles, and techniques of interpretation of drama from the point of view of the actor. In this first quarter we will focus on Greek Tragedy, perhaps the starkest form of drama. We will experiment with epic-sized characters expressing the deepest of human emotions, while trying to unite the voice work from sophomore year with an understanding of the text. We will experiment with different ideas in staging using some of the trappings of the period (masks, robes, headdress, shoes), with the ritual aspects of the dramas, with movement and sound. Also, and of utmost importance: the original thespians were men. I encourage all of you to explore all roles, without regard to sexual/gender identity. Women will play the male roles! Men will explore the female roles. This is quarter in which I challenge the students and their notions of identity.

name: History of Costume and Decor
subject: THEATRE
overview: This course follows the evolution of theatrical design and technology, asking: How did the plays of an era correspond with concurrent staging practices?  When did theatrical design transition from a codified form of representation into a medium for artistic expression?  What techniques and philosophies of past designers still speak to modern practice?  How does technology create new breakthroughs in design and performance? To explore these questions, this course will trace staging from its hillside origins in ancient Greece, through the revolutions that occurred in the early twentieth century, when artists like Adolph Appia and Alexandra Exter pioneered practical scenography, and up to the collaborative working models and new technologies that have carried director-designers like Julie Taymor into the twenty-first century. In addition to reading and participating in discussion, students will present on designers beyond the assigned syllabus, experiment with the techniques of industry innovators in class exercises, and engage in a practice as research final project that generates an extended design statement for a proposed production design.

name: Theatre of the Americas
subject: THEATRE
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Theatre Majors
overview: The course will encourage students to explore the nuance and power of amateurism within U.S. theatrical traditions.  Long denigrated as a term for lesser artists, students will examine the ways in which the concept of amateurism allowed the theatre to take hold within a nation traditionally suspicious of any theatrical activity.  The realm of amateur theatricals will be explored, as well as the growth of the not-for-profit establishment we know today, and even how these traditions may be reflected in do-it-yourself web channels and reality TV that we know today.  Students will be graded based on attendance, short written papers, a group project, and a final research paper.

name: Intro to Acting for the Screen
subject: THEATRE
requirements: Enrollment Requirements: Students must have taken RTVF 190-0 and either THEATRE 243-1 or 143-0 in order to register for this course.
overview:
This course will introduce RTVF and Theater students to the craft of acting for the screen. With an emphasis on the actor/director relationship, it will address practices for creating and portraying characters as well as the more technical concerns of how actors place themselves in relationship to the camera for the most effective appearance onscreen. Students in this course will perform in (and, in some cases, direct) a number of exercises to build acting skills in front of the camera, in projects - both in-class and out-of-class - designed to focus on cinematic storytelling achieved primarily through performance rather than primarily through directorial technique, cinematography, editing, and sound design.

Registration Requirements
Email Prof. Cone stephen.cone@northwestern.edu. To be considered, in your email you must indicate your class year and in which quarters you took the prerequisites: RTVF 190 and TH 143-0 or TH 243-1.

name: Graduate Colloquium
subject: THEATRE
overview: This class is a collaboration between the MFA directing students and the MFA playwrights as well as advanced undergraduate directors. Students in this advanced writing class will workshop a complete draft of a play that is 60 pages in length (the page limit will be expanded if the play is chosen for additional workshopping in the spring quarter). The full draft will be read out loud in class and MFA and advanced undergraduate directing students will workshop and present scenes from the play. Students will serve as actors during the reading and workshopping of the play. Students will be expected to workshop a recent work. An older project may be workshopped if it has undergone significant revisions. This is the first part of a two part class. The second part is a production class which will run in the spring. Four plays from part one of the class will be selected to receive workshop productions in part two. This will culminate in a weekend festival in June where the produced plays will be showcased.

overview: This course is designed to aid graduate director/dramaturg teams as they prepare for their productions. Readings and discussion about the nature of collaboration, as well as the tools and duties of the dramaturg, will be explored. In addition to the common reading, each team will be given various projects to complete that they will need to tailor to suit their specific production. While learning to work together, both the director and the dramaturg will also be learning intensive research skills, as well as how to apply that research to a real production environment, while thinking critically and writing persuasively about how and why that research is necessary and useful. Guest speakers will provide additional insight into the professional experience of the dramaturg at large.

name: Introduction to the Dance Experience
subject: DANCE
overview: This course introduces students to the field of Dance Studies. Focusing on the U.S. but including dance practices elsewhere, the course is not a comprehensive dance history but rather offers a series of various entry-points into the field. Approaching dance through film, scholarly texts, and digital platforms, we will ask how the dancing body is central to cultural history. We will learn to form scholarly inquiries about dance and to analyze it using both formalistic and theoretical frameworks. These include movement analysis and attention to representations of race, gender, sexuality, class, and nation. This course aims to better understand the sociohistorical and cultural contexts within which dance practices are embedded so that we are better equipped to recognize and unravel our own assumptions, hierarchies, and value-laden paradigms through which we think about and practice dance.

name: Modern III
subject: DANCE
overview: This course will explore modern dance under the umbrella of Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham, and Garth Fagan technique, some of the historical context from which it developed, and is currently performed. This modern technique class will offer all the elements of a level III. Through the use of the floor, standing and across the floor sequences, students will explore more advanced dance etiquette and terminology necessary to develop technique. The focus of this course is on developing flexibility, strength and stamina. Throughout this course we will explore the use of the back in order to gain a larger sense of the use of the torso/spine in modern dance. Students will also gain an understanding of the important contributions these choreographers, among others, have had on the development of modern dance. Complementary material such as videos and readings will be used in order to enhance the students experience in class

name: Mechanics II
subject: MECH_ENG
overview: Dry friction. Kinetics of rigid bodies in planar motion. Moments of inertia of rigid bodies. This course introduces students to the basic physical laws governing the the interaction of bodies. This course is essential for all future engineers, since all the objects in the world obey these laws, and no machine may be built without their knowledge.  Topics include: Velocities and accelerations of particles relative to any reference frame. Velocity and acceleration differences of any two particles. Relative angular velocities and angular accelerations of coplanar rigid slabs. Two-dimensional rolling. Mass centers and moments of inertia. Dynamics of a general collecton of particles: Linear momentum, angular momentum, and kinetic energy results of Newton's laws. Calculation of linear momentum, angular momentum, and kinetic energy of a rigid body in plane motion. Dynamics problems involving particles and rigid bodies in plane motion. Point mass and rigid body dynamics problems.

name: Thermodynamics & Statistical Mechanics - I
subject: MECH_ENG
overview: Basic definitions; Zeroth Law and the meaning of temperature; the First Law; the Second Law, entropy, and its applications; equations of state; the Third Law of Thermodynamics; and introduction to statistical thermodynamics.

name: Experimental Engineering
subject: MECH_ENG
overview: Modern electronics;  analog and digital circuit construction and conversion.  Modern data acquisition involving temperature measurements, control of stepper motors, transient heat transfer, fluid mechanics, deformation of beams.

subject: MECH_ENG
overview:
Catalog Description:
Introduction to strategy and methods of designing, manufacturing, and testing of mechanical products.  Material properties and selection methodology, engineering drawing and CAD, and simple manufacturing processes.
Course Description:
Introduction to methods and strategies for designing, manufacturing and testing of mechanical products. Topics include methodologies for material selection, engineering drawing, introduction to CAD, as well as an overview of simple manufacturing processes. For many students, mechanical engineering design is one of their first professional engineering courses - as distinguished from background courses in science and mathematics. Professional engineering is concerned with obtaining solutions to practical problems.

name: Fluid Mechanics I
subject: MECH_ENG
overview: Fundamentals of fluid mechanics.  Properties and statics of fluids.  Kinematics and dynamics of fluid motion-continuity, momentum and energy equations.  Dimensional analysis, flow in closed conduits.

overview:
Mechanical Engineering 314 
Theory of Machines - Dynamics

Catalog description

Three-dimensional kinematics: rotation axes and mechanism analysis, rotation matrices and Euler's angles for rigid bodies. Three-dimensional kinetics: dynamics of particles, central force problems, dynamics of rigid bodies, rotational inertia matrices and principal axes, dynamics of mechanisms, the gyroscope and other torque-free problems.


Who takes it

Mechanical engineering students often take this course during their third or fourth year.

name: Theory of Machines - Design of Elements
subject: MECH_ENG
overview: Factors influencing the proportioning of machine elements-stresses, deformations, and failure criteria as applied to shafts, springs, belts, bearings, gears. Lectures, Laboratory

name: Comp Integ Manufacturing: Manufacturing Processes
subject: MECH_ENG
overview:
Manufacturing processes: Analysis and evaluation of processes used in the contemporary manufacturing environment. Who takes it
ME 340-1 is taken by Mechanical Engineers, Manufacturing Engineers, and Industrial Engineers.
What it's about

This course is an introduction to the processes used in the contemporary manufacturing environment including casting, powder metal processing, polymer processing, machining, joining, metal forming, layered manufacturing and electronic materials processing. Process specific component design, material/processing interaction, tooling design and cost analysis will be covered.
